Call this function to direct the decoder to start decoding immediately as soon as an encoded frame is sent, if you are planning to decode at low frame rates. In this case, you must send one full encoded video frame buffer to be decoded.

Parameters:

  • handle - A decoding channel handle.
  • disable - Setting this field to true disables the decoder's internal pipeline. The default is false, which means the decoder's pipeline is enabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • This API should only be called with S6 chip-set. It has no affect in other Stretch chip-sets.
  • It is recommended that you do not disable decoder pipeline flushing for high frame rate decoding unless the loss in performance is acceptable.

See Also:

  • sdvr_enable_decoder() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_decoder_audio_mode (sdvr_chan_handle_t      handle,
                                        sdvr_enc_audio_mode_e   enc_audio_mode);

Call this function to specify whether the audio associated to this decoder is going to be mono or stereo. If this function is not called, the default is the encoded audio mode that was sepcified for the DVR board.

Parameters:

  • handle - A decoding channel handle.
  • mode - H.264 decoder operating mode. See sdvr_enc_audio_mode_e for different decoder modes and their meaning. NOTE: Set this field to SDVR_ENC_AUDIO_MODE_NONE to use the encoded audio mode settings that was specified for the board that the decoder channel is located.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_decoder_mode (sdvr_chan_handle_t         handle,
                                  sdvr_h264_decoder_mode_e   mode);

Call this function to configure the H.264 decoder mode. See sdvr_h264_decoder_mode_e for explaination and trade-offs between different decoder modes.

This function must be called before the video decoder is enabled and is only valid if decoding H.264 video frames.

Parameters:

  • handle - A decoding channel handle.
  • mode - H.264 decoder operating mode. See sdvr_h264_decoder_mode_e for different decoder modes and their meaning.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

See Also:

  • sdvr_enable_decoder() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_alloc_av_buffer_wait (sdvr_chan_handle_t    handle,
                                      sdvr_av_buffer_t   ** frame_buffer,
                                      sx_uint32             timeout);

This function is used to get a buffer from the SDK for the purpose of sending A/V data to the firmware. To decode video, the DVR Application first needs to call this function to get an empty buffer. The application then copies encoded video from the disk into this buffer.

After this buffer is full, it can be sent to the hardware for decoding using sdvr_send_av_frame(). Decoder buffers are released as part of the call to sdvr_send_av_frame(). In the event that a decoder buffer is acquired, but needs to be released without sending, you can call sdvr_release_av_buffer().

Each buffer can hold one encoded AV frame. For normal speed playback, the DVR Application needs to send 30 frames per second to the decoder.

The decoded data can be retrieved from the board using sdvr_get_stream_buffer() using the channel number that was used for decoding.

Buffers allocated this way should be returned as quickly as possible to the SDK, so that the decoder is not starved of data.

The returned buffer has the board and channel numbers, and other information embedded in the buffer data structure. This information has to be treated as read-only. Only the payload field in the sdvr_av_buffer_t structure can be modified by the DVR Application.

How to fill up the AV buffer? The buffer returned by this function is of type sdvr_av_buffer_t. Call sdvr_av_buf_payload() to get access payload buffer associated to this data structure as well as the size of the buffer. The frame buffer can be filled with the encoded data from disk. Then you must set the actaul payload size by calling sdvr_set_buffer_payload_size(). The frame type and timestamp can be set using sdvr_set_buffer_frame_type() and sdvr_set_buffer_timestamp() respectively.

NOTE: The board index, channel number, and channel types will be set to match the given channel handle upon successful return.

NOTE: This function can also be used to allocate a buffer that will contain raw video for using with a host encoder channel.

Parameters:

  • handle - A decoding channel handle.
  • frame_buffer - A pointer to the buffer variable that is set when this function returns.
  • timeout - Wait for this number of milliseconds for an available buffer before timing out.

Returns

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • Call sdvr_av_buf_payload() to get the size of allocated buffer.

See Also:

  • sdvr_send_av_frame(), sdvr_send_av_frame(), sdvr_release_av_buffer() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_alloc_av_buffer (sdvr_chan_handle_t    handle,
                                 sdvr_av_buffer_t   ** frame_buffer);

Convenience function equivalent to calling sdvr_alloc_av_buffer_wait with timeout set to 0. Returns immediately if no empty buffer available.

Parameters:

  • handle - A decoding channel handle.
  • frame_buffer - A pointer to the buffer variable that is set when this function returns.

Returns

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_send_av_frame (sdvr_av_buffer_t *frame_buffer);

The buffer obtained using sdvr_alloc_av_buffer() is filled with encoded data by the DVR Application, and then the buffer is sent to the decoder for decoding using this function.

You must set the timestamp assoicated with this buffer by calling sdvr_set_buffer_timestamp() in case the decoded bit-stream should be displayed on the SMO monitor. This timestamp must be based on 90Khz clock. In trick mode playback on the SMO, you can force the the decoded bit-stream to be displayed immediately by setting the timestamp to zero (0).

NOTE: Sending the buffer for decoding also implicitly returns the buffer to the SDK so that it can be used again in a future call to allocate a buffer.

Parameters:

  • frame_buffer - Pointer to the buffer to be sent. The channel number, board number, and so on are already a part of the buffer data structure.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • In case this function returns an error, it either must be called again until there is no error or call sdvr_release_av_buffer() to free the frame buffer.
  • The timestamp is only used for playback on the SMO and has no affect on decoding time.

10.10   Display and Sound API

sdvr_err_e sdvr_stream_raw_video (sdvr_chan_handle_t            handle,
                                  sdvr_video_res_decimation_e   res_decimation,
                                  sx_uint8                      frame_rate,
                                  sx_bool                       enable);

This function is used to enable streaming of primary raw video for a channel to the host. If the channel is an encoding channel, then the primary raw video is from the camera. If it is a decoding channel, the raw video is the decoded video.

This function can be called multiple times to enable and disable streaming.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • res_decimation - Specifies whether the video is streamed at the system-wide maximum resolution, or 1/4 (CIF), or 1/16 (QCIF), or 2CIF of that resolution. (NOTE: DCIF resolution is not supported).
  • frame_rate - Specifies the frame rate at which the raw video frames are being sent to the host application. In general this value should be 30. The valid range is 1 - maximum frame rate supported for the selected video standard. This field is ignored for decoder channels. The host DVR Application controls the frame rate by sending the encoded frames to be decoded at the desired rate.
  • enable - If true, streaming is enabled. Disabled otherwise.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • Resolution decimation and frame rate are ignored while disabling the raw video streaming.

See Also:

  • sdvr_stream_raw_video_secondary(), sdvr_stream_raw_audio() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_stream_raw_video_secondary (sdvr_chan_handle_t            handle,
                                            sdvr_video_res_decimation_e   res_decimation,
                                            sx_uint8                      frame_rate,
                                            sx_bool                       enable);

This function is used to enable streaming of secondary raw video for an encoding channel to the host. If the channel is an encoding channel, then the secondary raw video is from the camera.

This function can be called multiple times to enable and disable streaming.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • res_decimation - Specifies whether the video is streamed at the system-wide maximum resolution, or 1/4 (CIF), or 1/16 (QCIF), or 2CIF of that resolution. (NOTE: DCIF resolution is not supported).
  • frame_rate - Specifies the frame rate at which the raw video frames are being sent to the host application. In general this value should be 30. The valid range is 1 - 30.
  • enable - If true, streaming is enabled. Disabled otherwise.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • The secondary raw video streaming is not supported by decoding channel.
  • Resolution decimation and frame rate are ignored while disabling the raw video streaming.

See Also:

  • sdvr_stream_raw_video(), sdvr_stream_raw_audio() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_stream_raw_audio (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                  sx_bool              enable);

This function is used to enable streaming of raw audio for a channel to the host. If the channel is an encoding channel, then the raw audio is from the microphone. If it is a decoding channel, the raw audio is the decoded audio.

This function can be called multiple times to enable and disable streaming.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • enable - If true, streaming is enabled; otherwise, disabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

See Also:

  • sdvr_stream_raw_video_secondary(), sdvr_stream_raw_video() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_video_in_params (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sdvr_image_ctrl_t  * image_ctrl);

This function is used to get the current video-in image parameters when connected to a DVR/VRM board.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • image_ctrl - A pointer to sdvr_image_ctrl_t which holds the current video-in image parameter for the given upon successful return.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • Currently, this function is not support by any of the HD boards. You should call sdvr_get_img_properties() when connected to an IP-Camera.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_video_in_params(), sdvr_get_img_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_video_in_params (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sx_uint16            image_ctrl_flag,
                                     sdvr_image_ctrl_t  * image_ctrl);

This function is used to set various video-in image control parameters when connecting to a DVR/VRM board. You may choose to change one or more of the image control parameters. This is accomplished by setting the appropriate bit in the control parameter flag.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • image_ctrl_flag - A bit field indicating which of the fields in image_ctrl parameter needs to be updated. Use SDVR_ICFLAG_ALL to update all the video-in image control parameters. Or choose specific fields by ORing any of the image control flags (SDVR_ICFLAG_HUE, SDVR_ICFLAG_SATURATION, SDVR_ICFLAG_BRIGHTNESS, SDVR_ICFLAG_CONTRAST, and SDVR_ICFLAG_SHARPNESS).
  • image_ctrl - A pointer to sdvr_image_ctrl_t which holds the new video-in image parameter for the given. For each image control flag set in image_ctrl_flag parameter, you must have the corresponding value in image_ctrl data structure parameter. (See sdvr_image_ctrl_t for valid ranges and default values for each field in this structure.)

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • Changing these parameters could effect both alarms detection and encoding bit rate.
  • Currently, this function is not support by any of the HD boards.
  • You should call sdvr_set_img_properties() if connected to an IP-Camera.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_video_in_params(), sdvr_set_img_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_yuv_format (sx_uint32 board_index, sx_uint8 format);

By calling this function, you can specify the format by which the raw video frames should be constructed. This is a system wide setting that affects raw video streaming for both the decoded and live video frames. By default all the raw video frames are YUV 4:2:0 format.

Parameters:

  • board_index - The number of the board to set its raw video streaming format. This is a zero-based number. It means the first board number is index zero, the second board number is index one, and so on.
  • format - The requested YUV format. If the given format is not valid, it will default to SDVR_RAWV_FORMAT_YUV_4_2_0

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

This function should only be called if the board is in an idle state. This means there is no A/V encoding, decoding, or streaming. 

sdvr_err_e sdvr_enable_deinterlacing (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                      sx_bool              enable);

This function is used to enable or disable deinterlacing on the specified input channel.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle to an existing encoder or raw video channel.
  • enable - Set to True to enable deinterlacing, False to disable deinterlacing.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Deinterlacing is enabled by default. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_enable_pixel_adaptive_deinterlacing (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                                     sx_bool              enable);

This function is used to enable or disable pixel-level motion adaptive deinterlacing on the specified input channel.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle to an existing encoder or raw video channel.
  • enable - Set to True to enable deinterlacing, False to disable deinterlacing.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • The default deinterlacing method is disabled. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_enable_motion_based_deinterlacing (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                                   sx_bool              enable,
                                                   sx_uint8             threshold);

This function is used to enable or disable deinterlacing based on a specified motion threshold.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle to an existing video encoder or raw video channel.
  • enable - If this field is set to true, then the video pre-processor (VPP) performs weave deinterlacing. The default value is true.
  • threshold - A threshold value to be used to decided whether to perform weave deinterlacing. If motion based deinterlacing is set to be enabled, the VPP performs weave deinterlacing as long as the detected motion value is less than or equal to the this value. When the detected motion exceeds this value, VPP will switch to median filtering for deinterlacing. A value of zero disables this action.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • The median filter setting as result of the call to sdvr_enable_median_filter() is ignored if motion based deinterlacing is enabled. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_enable_median_filter (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                      sx_bool              enable);

This function is used to enable or disable median filtering as part of deinterlacing on the specified input channel.

If this action is disabled then the two fields will be weaved together but no filtering will be performed.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle to an existing encoder or raw video channel.
  • enable - Set to True to enable median filtering, False to disable. The default value is enabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • The median filtering is ignored if deinterlacing is disabled by calling sdvr_enable_deinterlacing(). 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_enable_noise_reduction (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                        sx_bool              enable);

This function is used to enable or disable Stretch-lateral noise reduction filtering on the specified input channel.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle to an existing encoder or raw video channel.
  • enable - Set to True to enable noise reduction, False to disable noise reduction.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • noise reduction is enabled by default. The default values of luma and chroma strengths are 2 and 0 respectively. To set values of luma and chroma specified by user, the API function sdvr_set_noise_reduction_strength() should be called. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_noise_reduction_strength (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                              sx_uint8             luma_strength,
                                              sx_uint8             chroma_strength);

This function is used to set values of luma and chroma strengths associated with the noise reduction filter.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle to an existing encoder or raw video channel.
  • luma_strength - The value of luma strength to be set. The valid range is between 0 and 5.
  • chroma_strength - The value of luma strength to be set. The valid range is between 0 and 5.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is used to set values of luma and chroma strengths associated with the noise reduction filter. To enable the noise reduction filter call sdvr_enable_noise_reduction(). 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_noise_reduction_strength (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                              sx_uint8           * luma_strength,
                                              sx_uint8           * chroma_strength);

This function is used to get values of luma and chroma strengths.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle to an existing encoder or raw video channel.
  • luma_strength - The pointer to a sx_uin8 data which holds the value of luma strength set in firmware.
  • chroma_strength - The pointer to a sx_uin8 data which holds the value of chroma strength set in firmware.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_gain_mode (sdvr_chan_handle_t handle, sx_uint8 value);

This function is used to adjust the gain on the specified camera input.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle to an existing encoder or raw video channel.
  • value - Gain setting value. This value will be passed through as-is to the hardware. The range is 0 - 255.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Default values for this field is hardware specific. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_camera_termination (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                        sdvr_term_e          term);

This function sets the camera termination impedance value.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of the channel to be affected.
  • term - Enumerated constant defining the termination value.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • The default termination value is SDVR_TERM_75OHM. This feature is not supported on all Stretch boards. Boards that do not support this feature will return an unsupported command error. Contact Stretch technical support for details of boards that support this feature. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_enable_audio_out (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                  sx_uint8             aout_port_num,
                                  sx_bool              enable);

Call this function to activate playing of audio frames sent to the specified audio-out port or to mute audio on this port.

For decode channels, the encoded audio frames come from the Host DVR Application. Whereas, for encode channels, audio frames are from the audio-in port corresponding to the camera. After the audio-out port for a camera or encode channel is enabled, the live audio will be immediately played regardless of the current state of raw audio streaming.

NOTE: You must first disable the previously enabled audio out port before enabling of audio for a new live audio, decoded channel, or sending the raw audio to the audio out port.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid.
  • aout_port_num - The audio-out port number where the first port number is one (1).
  • enable - If set to true, the audio associated with the given channel will be played. Set this field to false to mute audio on this audio-out port.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • This function is only available on firmware version 5.2 or later.
  • You may call this function multiple times in order to send the live or decoded audio frames from a specific channel to multiple audio-out ports. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_start_audio_out (sx_uint32            board_index,
                                 sx_uint8             aout_port_num,
                                 sdvr_chan_handle_t * handle);

This function initializes the audio output port on the specified board to send raw audio frames from the DVR Application to be played on the specified audio-out port.

After the audio output port is initialized, you should call sdvr_alloc_av_buffer(), fill it with raw audio frames, and send it to the board by calling sdvr_send_av_frame().

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to send the video.
  • aout_port_num - The audio-out port number starting from port number 1.
  • handle - Pointer to storage for the output channel handle, filled in on return. This handle should be used for all the subsequent call related to sending of audio frames to this audio-out port number.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • You should make sure that the specified audio-out port number is not in use by any other live or decode audio streaming. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_stop_audio_out (sdvr_chan_handle_t handle);

This function shuts down the audio output port on the specified board. After calling this function, you can not send any more raw audio to the audio-out port.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel to close. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_audio_out().

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_enable_ir_cut_filter (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                      sx_bool              enable);

This function is used to enable or disable the Infrared (IR) cut-off filter on the sensor of an IP-Camera. An IR cut-off filter blocks the transmission of the infrared while passing the visible.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • enable - If set to true, IR cut filter for the lens is enabled only if the camera lens has IR cut filter support. Otherwise, it will be disabled. The default enable state of the IR cut filter is board specific. As a result, it must be set to guarantee its state.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • This command is not supported by DVR firmwares. Additionally, it only will have any affect on IP-Cameras that have a hardware support for it. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_snapshot (sdvr_chan_handle_t            handle,
                          sdvr_video_res_decimation_e   resolution);

This function takes a JPEG image of the latest encoded or EMO video frame on the given channel. After this function is called, a video frame of SDVR_FRAME_JPEG_SNAPSHOT type will be generated and can be retrieved once the registered streaming callback is called.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding/EMO channel handle.
  • resolution - The resolution of the snapshot video frame. The supported resolutions for encoding channels are: SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_EQUAL, SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_FOURTH, or SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_SIXTEENTH. EMO channels only support SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_EQUAL.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • The snapshot images are not queued. As a result, if this function is called multiple times for a given channel prior to retrieving the video frame, only the last video image is returned. Additionally, the snapshot images will be lost if the previously taken snapshot image was not released before taking a new snapshot for the same channel.
  • This feature is not supported by boards that are using S6 chipset.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_stream_buffer() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_snapshot_ex (sdvr_chan_handle_t            handle,
                             sdvr_video_res_decimation_e   resolution,
                             sx_uint16                     width,
                             sx_uint16                     height);

This function takes a JPEG image of the latest encoded or EMO video frame on the given channel. After this function is called, a video frame of SDVR_FRAME_JPEG_SNAPSHOT type will be generated and can be retrieved once the registered streaming callback is called.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding/EMO channel handle.
  • resolution - The resolution of the snapshot video frame. The supported resolutions for encoding channels are: SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_EQUAL, SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_FOURTH, SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_SIXTEENTH, or DVR_VIDEO_RES_CUSTOM. EMO channels only support SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_EQUAL.
  • width - custom width of snapshot, has to be multiple of 16 and greater than 64
  • height - custom height of snapshot, has to be even number and greater than 64

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • The snapshot images are not queued. As a result, if this function is called multiple times for a given channel prior to retrieving the video frame, only the last video image is returned. Additionally, the snapshot images will be lost if the previously taken snapshot image was not released before taking a new snapshot for the same channel.
  • This feature is not supported by boards that are using S6 chipset.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_stream_buffer()

10.11   On-Screen Display API

sdvr_err_e sdvr_osd_text_config_ex (sdvr_chan_handle_t     handle,
                                    sx_uint8               osd_id,
                                    sdvr_osd_config_ex_t * osd_text_config);

This function is used to configure the OSD text for an OSD item on all the video streams (HMO, encoded, and SMOs). The text associated with each OSD item can be up to 100 characters long but the actual display is limited to the size of the video and the starting location of the text. Additionally, you can specify whether to append a timestamp to the displayed text. Appending a time stamp reduces the number of characters that can be displayed for your OSD item.

After you configure an OSD item, you can show or hide its display state by calling sdvr_osd_text_show(). The original state of the OSD item is hidden.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured; where, osd_id zero corresponds to the first OSD, 1 to the second, and so on. The valid range is 0 to 4 in version 5.1 or later and 0 to 1 prior to version 5.1.
  • osd_text_config - This data structure defines the text and its position for display over the video for the given channel as well as whether a timestamp should be appended to the text.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • Call sdvr_smo_osd_text_config() to selectively configure the OSD text on a specific SMO port. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_osd_set_text (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                              sx_uint8             osd_id,
                              sx_uint8             text_len,
                              sx_uint16          * text);

This function is used to change the text for an OSD item on all the video streams (HMO, encoded, and SMOs). The text associated with each OSD item can be up to 100 characters long but the actual display is limited to the size of the video and the starting location of the text. After you configure an OSD item, you can show or hide its display state by calling sdvr_osd_text_show(). The original state of the OSD item is hidden.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured; where, osd_id zero corresponds to the first OSD, 1 to the second, and so on. The valid range is 0 to 4 in version 5.1 or later and 0 to 1 prior to version 5.1.
  • text_len - The number of unsigned double byte characters in the OSD text parameter.
  • text - Up to 100 unsigned double byte Unicode text to be displayed.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • Call sdvr_osd_text_config_ex() to set the location of OSD text, append timestamp, as well as specifying the text. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_osd_text_show (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                               sx_uint8             osd_id,
                               sx_bool              show);

This function is used to control the display state of an OSD item for a given channel. The OSD text is displayed as soon as encoding, raw video, or SMO streaming is enabled for the current channel handle. Changing the video streaming has no affect on the display state of an OSD item for the given channels.

This function must be called only after an OSD item is configured by calling sdvr_osd_text_config_ex() for the given channel handle.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to show or hide; where, osd_id zero corresponds to the first OSD, 1 to the second, and so on. The valid range is 0 to 4 in version 5.1 or later and 0 to 1 prior to version 5.1.
  • show - If true, OSD item is displayed; otherwise, it is not displayed.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • This function controls the display state of OSD text on all the video stream (HMO, encoded, and SMO). Call sdvr_smo_osd_text_show() to selectively change the display state of OSD text on a specific video stream for this channel. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_osd_text_show_all (sdvr_chan_handle_t handle, sx_bool show);

This function controls the display state of all OSD text items that have been configured for the given channel. The OSD text is displayed as soon as encoding, raw video, or SMO streaming is enabled for the specified channel handle.

Changing the video streaming has no affect on the display state of an OSD item on this channel.

This function must be called only after all the OSD texts are configured by calling sdvr_osd_text_config_ex() for the given channel handle.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • show - If true, all the OSD items are displayed at the same time; otherwise, they all get turned off.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • This function controls the display state of OSD text on all the video stream (HMO, encoded, and SMO). Call sdvr_smo_osd_text_show() to selectively change the display state of OSD text on a specific video stream for this channel. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_osd_blinking_on (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                 sx_uint8             osd_id,
                                 sx_uint8             on_frame_counts,
                                 sx_uint8             off_frame_counts,
                                 sx_uint32            flags);

This function controls whether any OSD text item associated to an encoder channel needs to be blinking under certain specified conditions.

The actual OSD text display is controlled by the sdvr_osd_text_show_all() or sdvr_osd_text_show() unless an alarm blinking flag is specified. In case an alarm blinking condition is specified but the OSD text is not shown by default, the OSD will be displayed and starts blinking once the corresponding alarm is triggered. The blinking continues until sdvr_osd_blinking_off() is called. The OSD blinking needs to be reset by calling this function again.

This function must be called only after all the OSD texts are configured by calling sdvr_osd_text_config_ex() for the given channel handle.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to blink; where, osd_id zero corresponds to the first OSD, 1 to the second, and so on. The valid range is 0 to 4 in version 5.1 or later and 0 to 1 prior to version 5.1.
  • on_frame_counts - Number of frames to show the OSD text for the specified OSD item.
  • off_frame_counts - Number of frames to hide the OSD text for the specified OSD item.
  • flags - Blink control flags. See sdvr_osd_blink_e for detailed information. A value of zero (0) in this field means blink the OSD text until it is turned off by calling sdvr_osd_blinking_off()

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • Blinking of OSD text is supported only on camera OSD text. It is not supported on SMO OSD text or on decode channels. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_osd_blinking_off (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                  sx_uint8             osd_id);

This function disables the blinking of the OSD text item.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to turn of its blinking; where, osd_id zero corresponds to the first OSD, 1 to the second, and so on. The valid range is 0 to 4 in version 5.1 or later and 0 to 1 prior to version 5.1.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • This function does not hide the OSD text item. The actual display is controlled by the sdvr_osd_text_show_all() or sdvr_osd_text_show() functions. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_osd_set_font_table (sdvr_font_table_t *font_desc);

Use this function to specify a different OSD text display font table than the default ASCII font. Currently, Bitmap Distribution Format (BDF) is the only supported font format. (The BDF by Adobe is a file format for storing bitmap fonts. BDF is the most commonly used font file within the Linux operating system.)

The new font table is used for all the DVR boards that are connected at the time of calling sdvr_osd_set_font_table(). You can either choose to use all the characters within the font table or a subset of it. (To use all the characters, set start_font_code parameter to 0 and end_font_code parameter to 65535.) Alternatively, you may select to only send characters in the font table that are used in your OSD text. This method constructs a new font table as needed every time you set a new OSD text. To use the latter method, set both the start_font_code parameter and end_font_code parameter to 0. This method may have some performance affect as font table gets constructed dynamically while setting the OSD text but uses less memory.

The specified YUV font color is used for all the characters within the table.

Parameters:

  • font_desc - A pointer to font descriptor data structure defining the new font table to load.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • It is recommended to call this function once and after you are connected to all the DVR boards but before any kind of video streaming. Some characters in the OSD text maybe missing if this function is called after setting of OSD text. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_osd_use_font_table (sx_uint8 font_id);

After you down load font tables into the firmware by calling sdvr_osd_set_font_table(), you can select which font table to use. By default, the last font table down loaded is selected. If no, font table is specified, the default English font table is used.

Font table IDs of less than 8 are reserved for predefined system fonts. Currently, there is only one system font ID SDVR_FT_FONT_ENGLISH defined.

Parameters:

  • font_id - The font table ID to be selected.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • The given font table is used for all the DVR boards that are connected at the time of calling this function.

10.12   Flexible On-Screen Display API

sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_get_cap (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                              sdvr_fosd_msg_cap_t      * fosd_cap);

This function is used to query the capability of the FOSD of a job. Call this function first and then call sdvr_fosd_spec to set the FOSD specification of a job.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • fosd_cap - This data structure returns the capability of the FOSD of a job.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • Please refer sdvr_fosd_msg_cap_t for the settings of this data structure. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_spec (const sdvr_chan_handle_t    handle,
                           const sdvr_fosd_msg_cap_t * fosd_spec);

This function is used to specify the use of the FOSD of a job. Call this function first before any FOSD configurations.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • fosd_spec - This data structure specifies the use of the FOSD of a job. Its valuses should not be larger than their corresponding values returned by sdvr_fosd_get_cap.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • Please refer sdvr_fosd_msg_cap_t for the settings of this data structure. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_config (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                             const sx_uint16            osd_id,
                             const sdvr_fosd_config_t * fosd_config);

This function is used to configure the OSD text for an OSD item on all the video streams (HMO, encoded, and SMOs). The text associated with each OSD item can be up to 100 characters long but the actual display is limited to the size of the video and the starting location of the text. Additionally, you can specify whether to append a timestamp to the displayed text. Appending a time stamp reduces the number of characters that can be displayed for your OSD item.

After you configure an OSD item, you can show or hide its display state by calling sdvr_fosd_show. The original state of the OSD item is hidden.

It also checks the availability of font table specified by font_table_id of fosd_config and returns DVR_STATUS_FONT_NOT_AVAILABLE if the specified font table has not been added yet.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured. It is composed of 3 items - module, stream, and text IDs. Please use SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID to construct an OSD ID.
  • fosd_config - This data structure defines the text and its position for display over the video for the given channel as well as whether a timestamp should be appended to the text.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_set_text (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                               const sx_uint16            osd_id,
                               const sx_uint8             font_table_id,
                               const sx_uint8             text_len,
                               const sx_uint16          * text);

This function is used to change the text for an OSD item on all the video streams (HMO, encoded, and SMOs). The text associated with each OSD item can be up to 100 characters long but the actual display is limited to the size of the video and the starting location of the text. After you configure an OSD item, you can show or hide its display state by calling sdvr_fosd_show. The original state of the OSD item is hidden.

It also checks the availability of font table specified by font_table_id and returns DVR_STATUS_FONT_NOT_AVAILABLE if the specified font table has not been added yet.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured. It is composed of 3 items - module, stream, and text IDs. Please use SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID to construct an OSD ID.
  • font_table_id - the font table ID of this OSD text line. Its valid range is 0 to 15. The default value is 0. If a font table of this ID is not available, no OSD is shown. User defined font table IDs are from 8 to 15, IDs 0 to 7 are reserved for system fonts.
  • text_len - The number of unsigned double byte characters in the OSD text parameter.
  • text - Up to 100 unsigned double byte Unicode text to be displayed. Some of texts are chopped if it is beyond the max_width_cap specified by sdvr_fosd_spec.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • Call sdvr_fosd_config first to set the location of OSD text, append timestamp, as well as specifying the text. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_set_graphic (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                  const sx_uint16            osd_id,
                                  const sx_uint16            width,
                                  const sx_uint16            height,
                                  const sx_uint8           * bitmap);

This function is used to change the text for an OSD item in graphic mode.

After you configure an OSD item, you can show or hide its display state by calling sdvr_fosd_show. The original state of the OSD item is hidden.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured. It is composed of 3 items - module, stream, and text IDs. Please use SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID to construct an OSD ID.
  • width, height - the width and height of this bitmap in pixel.
  • bitmap - The bitmap of this OSD.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • Call sdvr_fosd_config first to set the location of OSD text, append timestamp, as well as specifying the text.
  • It is not supported at the current release yet. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_clear_text (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                 const sx_uint16            osd_id);

This function is used to clear the text, including graphics, for an OSD item.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured. It is composed of 3 items - module, stream, and text IDs. Please use SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID to construct an OSD ID.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • Call sdvr_fosd_config first to set the location of OSD text, append timestamp, as well as specifying the text. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_show (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                           const sx_uint16            osd_id,
                           const sx_bool              show);

This function is used to control the display state of an OSD item for a given channel. The OSD text is displayed as soon as encoding, raw video, or SMO streaming is enabled for the current channel handle. Changing the video streaming has no affect on the display state of an OSD item for the given channels.

This function must be called only after an OSD item is configured by calling sdvr_fosd_config for the given channel handle.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured. It is composed of 3 items - module, stream, and text IDs. Please use SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID to construct an OSD ID.
  • show - If true, OSD item is displayed; otherwise, it is not displayed.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_show_all (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                               const sx_bool              show);

This function controls the display state of all OSD text items that have been configured for the given channel. The OSD text is displayed as soon as encoding, raw video, or SMO streaming is enabled for the specified channel handle.

Changing the video streaming has no affect on the display state of an OSD item on this channel.

This function must be called only after all the OSD texts are configured by calling sdvr_fosd_config for the given channel handle.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding or decoding channel handle.
  • show - If true, all the OSD items are displayed at the same time; otherwise, they all get turned off.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_blinking_on (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                  const sx_uint16            osd_id,
                                  const sx_uint8             on_frames,
                                  const sx_uint8             off_frames,
                                  const sx_uint32            flags);

This function controls whether any OSD text item associated to an encoder channel needs to be blinking under certain specified conditions.

The actual OSD text display is controlled by the sdvr_fosd_show_all or sdvr_fosd_show unless an alarm blinking flag is specified. In case an alarm blinking condition is specified but the OSD text is not shown by default, the OSD will be displayed and starts blinking once the corresponding alarm is triggered. The blinking continues until sdvr_fosd_blinking_off is called. The OSD blinking needs to be reset by calling this function again.

This function must be called only after all the OSD texts are configured by calling sdvr_fosd_config for the given channel handle.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured. It is composed of 3 items - module, stream, and text IDs. Please use SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID to construct an OSD ID.
  • on_frames - Number of frames to show the OSD text for the specified OSD item.
  • off_frames - Number of frames to hide the OSD text for the specified OSD item.
  • flags - Blink control flags. See sdvr_osd_blink_e for detailed information. If flag SDVR_OSD_BLINK_ALWAYS in this field is on, it means blink the OSD text until it is turned off by calling sdvr_fosd_blinking_off

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • Blinking of OSD text for alarm flags is supported only on OSD texts of encoder jobs. At the current release, a decoder job does not run analytics so it does not blink for alarm. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_blinking_off (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                   const sx_uint16            osd_id);

This function disables the blinking of the OSD text item.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured. It is composed of 3 items - module, stream, and text IDs. Please use SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID to construct an OSD ID.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remark:

  • This function does not hide the OSD text item. The actual display is controlled by the sdvr_fosd_show_all or sdvr_fosd_show functions. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_set_color (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                const sx_uint16            osd_id,
                                const sx_uint8             color_y,
                                const sx_uint8             color_u,
                                const sx_uint8             color_v,
                                const sx_uint8             color_high_y,
                                const sx_uint8             color_high_u,
                                const sx_uint8             color_high_v,
                                const sx_uint8             color_low_y,
                                const sx_uint8             color_low_u,
                                const sx_uint8             color_low_v);

This function sets the color of an OSD, including translucent setting.

This function must be called only after all the OSD texts are configured by calling sdvr_fosd_config for the given channel handle.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured. It is composed of 3 items - module, stream, and text IDs. Please use SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID to construct an OSD ID.
  • color_y, color_u, color_v - the color of an OSD
  • color_high_y, color_high_u, color_high_v - the translucent color of an OSD
  • color_low_y, color_low_u, color_low_v - the translucent color of an OSD

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_fosd_set_position (const sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                   const sx_uint16            osd_id,
                                   const sdvr_location_e      position_ctrl,
                                   const sx_uint16            pos_x,
                                   const sx_uint16            pos_y);

This function sets the position of an OSD.

This function must be called only after all the OSD texts are configured by calling sdvr_fosd_config for the given channel handle.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encoding channel handle.
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured. It is composed of 3 items - module, stream, and text IDs. Please use SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID to construct an OSD ID.
  • position_ctrl - position control setting
  • pos_x, pos_y - the position of this OSD

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

10.13   Spot Monitor Output API

sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_set_disable_mode (sx_uint32                 board_index,
                                      sx_uint8                  port_num,
                                      sdvr_smo_disable_mode_e   mode);

This function sets the action to take place after the last grid on the specified SMO port is disabled.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Zero based index of the DVR board to query its SMO information.
  • port_num - The video out port number starting from port number 1.
  • mode - The SMO display disable mode. Refer to sdvr_smo_disable_mode_e for options available after the SMO port is disabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is not supported by all the DVR boards.

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_set_grid() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_smo_video_vstd (sx_uint32          board_index,
                                    sx_uint8           port_num,
                                    sdvr_video_std_e   video_std);

This function sets a new video standard for the specified SMO port on a given board.

By default each SMO port inherits the default video standard of the board that was selected at board connect. This video standard can be changed to other supported video standards on a SMO port. You may call sdvr_get_smo_attributes() to query for all the supported video standards before calling this function.

This function must be called after connecting to a board but before creating any channels on that board.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Zero based index of the DVR board to query its SMO information.
  • port_num - The video out port number starting from port number 1.
  • video_std - The new video standard of the SMO port.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function requires firmware version 7.0.0.0 or higher. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_smo_attributes (sx_uint32              board_index,
                                    sx_uint8               port_num,
                                    sdvr_smo_attribute_t * smo_attrib);

This function returns various attributes associated with the requested Spot Monitor Out (SMO). Call this function to find out the SMO screen size.

If connecting to a firmware version of 7.0.0.0 or higher by calling this function, you can also get a list of all the supported video standards on the request SMO port.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Zero based index of the DVR board to query its SMO information.
  • port_num - The video out port number starting from port number 1.
  • smo_attrib - A structure to hold the attribute of the requested SMO port.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_smo_bkg_color (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                   sx_uint8    port_num,
                                   sx_uint8    y_bg_color,
                                   sx_uint8    u_bg_color,
                                   sx_uint8    v_bg_color);

This function sets the background color for the specified SMO port on the given board. The background color is specified in terms of YUV color. By default the background color of the SMO display is set to black.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Zero-based index of the DVR board where the SMO display reside on.
  • port_num - The video out port number starting from port number 1.
  • y_bg_color - The y component of the background color.
  • u_bg_color - The u component of the background color.
  • v_bg_color - The v component of the background color.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • You can convert RGB to YUV420 by the following formula:
  • y = ((306 * r + 601 * g + 117 * b + 512) >> 10);
  • u = ((-172 * r - 340 * g + 512 * b + 512) >> 10) + 128;
  • v = ((512 * r - 429 * g - 83 * b + 512) >> 10) + 128; 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_smo_grid_ex (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                 sx_uint8             port_num,
                                 sdvr_smo_grid_t    * smo_grid);

NOTE: This is a deprecated function and replaced with sdvr_smo_set_grid() as of release 7.7.0.0.

This function is used to set the Spot Monitor Output (SMO) grid pattern for a specific SMO display.

You can divide the SMO into different grid patterns. Each tile of the SMO grid is defined by its left top most coordinate in pixels, and by the decimation of its original video resolution. Additionally, you can resize the grid either larger or smaller than the specified decimated video size.

The grid pattern on a spot monitor is flexible and can be defined in various patterns (such as 4x4, 3x3, or 8x8 grids) as it applies to the resolution of the connected monitor.

Each tile of the grid is described by an sdvr_smo_grid_t data structure.

Each tile can either be enabled or disabled. If you have more than one channel in one tile position, you must also specify a dwell time, that is, the amount of time each channel is displayed before switching to the next channel. (This feature is not currently supported.) If you only have one channel assigned to a tile, that channel is permanently displayed while it is enabled.

NOTE: You can include encoder and decoder channels in the SMO tile. For encoder channels, the live video is displayed. For decoder channels, the decoded (playback) video is displayed.

You can assign multiple channels to a tile, but a specific channel cannot be assigned to different tiles.

Assuming your SMO is an NTSC monitor of 720x480 resolution, and you want to specify 16 tiles arranged in a 4x4 grid pattern, then each tile is 180x120. The first left top most grid is (0,0) the next one is (180,120), and so on. The resolution decimation for each grid is 1/4 of the camera resolution.

NOTE: The top left coordinates of each tile must be an even number (i.e., coordinates (0,5) or (1,2) are invalid).

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid. See section Spot Monitor Output (SMO) for restriction in using decode video channel handle.
  • port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).
  • smo_grid - A pointer structure defining one grid on an SMO. Supported SMO resolution decimations are SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_EQUAL, SDVR_VIDEO_RES_CIF, and SDVR_VIDEO_RES_QCIF.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • The SMO grid is not displayed at all if it does not fit completely on the screen.

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_set_grid() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_set_grid (sdvr_chan_handle_t      handle,
                              sx_uint8                instance_id,
                              sx_uint8                port_num,
                              const sdvr_smo_grid_t * smo_grid);

This function is used to set the Spot Monitor Output (SMO) grid pattern for a specific SMO display.

You can divide the SMO into different grid patterns. Each tile of the SMO grid is defined by its left top most coordinate in pixels, and by the decimation of its original video resolution. Additionally, you can resize the grid either larger or smaller than the specified decimated video size.

The grid pattern on a spot monitor is flexible and can be defined in various patterns (such as 4x4, 3x3, or 8x8 grids) as it applies to the resolution of the connected monitor.

Each tile of the grid is described by an sdvr_smo_grid_t data structure.

Each tile can either be enabled or disabled. If you have a channel assigned to a tile, that channel is permanently displayed while it is enabled.

Same channel can be displayed in multiple grids within a SMO display but it is limited to 4 instances on the same display.

NOTE: You can include encoder and decoder channels in the SMO tile. For encoder channels, the live video is displayed. For decoder channels, the decoded (playback) video is displayed.

Assuming your SMO is an NTSC monitor of 720x480 resolution, and you want to specify 16 tiles arranged in a 4x4 grid pattern, then each tile is 180x120. The first left top most grid is (0,0) the next one is (180,120), and so on. The resolution decimation for each grid is 1/4 of the camera resolution.

NOTE: The top left coordinates of each tile must be an even number (i.e., coordinates (0,5) or (1,2) are invalid).

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid. See section Spot Monitor Output (SMO) for restriction in using decode video channel handle.
  • instance_id - You can display the same encoder or decoder handle in upto 4 grids within a SMO display. This field is used to identify each one of such grids. Valid range is 0 - 3.
  • port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).
  • smo_grid - A pointer structure defining one grid on an SMO. Supported SMO resolution decimations are SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_EQUAL, SDVR_VIDEO_RES_CIF, and SDVR_VIDEO_RES_QCIF.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • The SMO grid is not displayed at all if it does not fit completely on the screen.
  • This function needs firmware version 7.7.0.11 or heigher. For the older firmware instance_id is ignored and only one instance of each channel can exist on a SMO monitor.

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_get_grid() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_smo_grid_ex (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                 sx_uint8             port_num,
                                 sdvr_smo_grid_t    * smo_grid);

NOTE: This is a deprecated function and replaced with sdvr_smo_get_grid() as of release 7.7.0.0.

This function is used to get the current SMO grid configuration for a given SMO display

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid.
  • port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).
  • smo_grid - A pointer structure defining one grid on an SMO.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_get_grid (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                              sx_uint8             instance_id,
                              sx_uint8             port_num,
                              sdvr_smo_grid_t    * smo_grid);

This function is used to get the current SMO grid configuration for a given SMO display

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid.
  • instance_id - The instantiation ID for this SMO grid. This is the same ID as what you used to enable the grid while calling sdvr_smo_set_grid().
  • port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).
  • smo_grid - [output] A pointer structure defining one grid on an SMO.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.
  • This function needs firmware version 7.7.0.11 or heigher. For the older firmware instance_id is ignored and only one instance of each channel can exist on a SMO monitor.

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_set_grid() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_flush_queue (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                 sx_uint8             port_num);

This function clears the video frame queue for the given encoder/decoder on the specified SMO port. This function is mostly needed for the trick playback.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle to clear its corresponding video frame queue on the SMO port.
  • port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes. NOTE: The success status code returned from this API does not necessary indicate if the command was executed by the firmware.

Remarks:

  • This function is not supported by all the DVR boards. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_zoom_grid (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                               sx_uint8             instance_id,
                               sx_uint8             smo_port_num,
                               sx_uint16            top_left_x,
                               sx_uint16            top_left_y,
                               sx_uint16            width,
                               sx_uint16            height);

Call this function to zoom a rectangular region within an SMO grid into the existing SMO grid region. The top-left corner of zoom region is relative to the top-left corner of the SMO grid and not the screen.

The SMO grid must have been enabled before this function can be called. The SMO grid is enabled by calling sdvr_smo_set_grid().

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid.
  • instance_id - The instantiation ID for this SMO grid. This is the same ID as what you used to enable the grid while calling sdvr_smo_set_grid().
  • smo_port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).
  • top_left_x, top_left_y - These two numbers specify the top-left coordinates of the zoom region based on screen resolution pixels relative to the top left corner of the SMO grid. These coordinates must be even number values. The coordinates of the top-left corner is indicated by (0,0).
  • width - This is the width of the zoom region based on screen resolution pixels. A value of zero cancels the zoom and uses the original grid resolution and size. Width of any zoom region must be an even value larger than or equal to 8.
  • height - This is the height of the zoom region based on screen resolution pixels. A value of zero cancels the zoom and uses the original grid resolution and size. Height of any zoom region must be an even value larger than or equal to 8.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. NOTE: For performance reasons, this function does not wait for any response to be returned from the firmware. As result, there could be errors detected by the firmware that will not be returned. (e.g., the given coordinates maybe outside of the SMO grid.)

Remarks:

  • This function requires firmware version 7.7 or higher. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_zoom_smo_grid (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                               sx_uint8             smo_port_num,
                               sx_uint16            top_left_x,
                               sx_uint16            top_left_y,
                               sx_uint16            width,
                               sx_uint16            height);

NOTE: This is a deprecated function and replaced with sdvr_smo_zoom_grid() as of release 7.7.0.0.

Call this function to zoom a rectangular region within an SMO grid into the existing SMO grid region. The top-left corner of zoom region is relative to the top-left corner of the SMO grid and not the screen.

The SMO grid must have been enabled before this function can be called. The SMO grid is enabled by calling sdvr_smo_set_grid().

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid.
  • smo_port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).
  • top_left_x, top_left_y - These two numbers specify the top-left coordinates of the zoom region based on screen resolution pixels relative to the top left corner of the SMO grid. These coordinates must be even number values. The coordinates of the top-left corner is indicated by (0,0).
  • width - This is the width of the zoom region based on screen resolution pixels. A value of zero cancels the zoom and uses the original grid resolution and size. Width of any zoom region must be an even value larger than or equal to 8.
  • height - This is the height of the zoom region based on screen resolution pixels. A value of zero cancels the zoom and uses the original grid resolution and size. Height of any zoom region must be an even value larger than or equal to 8.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. NOTE: For performance reasons, this function does not wait for any response to be returned from the firmware. As result, there could be errors detected by the firmware that will not be returned. (e.g., the given coordinates maybe outside of the SMO grid.)

Remarks:

  • This function requires firmware version 5.2 or higher. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_pause_grid (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                sx_uint8             instance_id,
                                sx_uint8             smo_port_num,
                                sx_bool              pause);

This function pauses or resumes the video for a single SMO grid on the video output port on the specified board. Any video frames, live or decode, that is sent to a SMO grid which is in pause mode is discarded.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid.
  • instance_id - The instantiation ID for this SMO grid. This is the same ID as what you used to enable the grid while calling sdvr_smo_set_grid().
  • smo_port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).
  • pause - Set to true to freeze the last video frame on the SMO port for the specified camera or decoder. A value of false resumes streaming of the video frames.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes. NOTE: The success status code returned from this API does not necessary indicate if the command was executed by the firmware. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_pause_smo_grid (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                sx_uint8             smo_port_num,
                                sx_bool              pause);

NOTE: This is a deprecated function and replaced with sdvr_smo_pause_grid() as of release 7.7.0.0.

This function pauses or resumes the video for a single SMO grid on the video output port on the specified board. Any video frames, live or decode, that is sent to a SMO grid which is in pause mode is discarded.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid.
  • smo_port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).
  • pause - Set to true to freeze the last video frame on the SMO port for the specified camera or decoder. A value of false resumes streaming of the video frames.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes. NOTE: The success status code returned from this API does not necessary indicate if the command was executed by the firmware. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_grid_mirror_image (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                       sx_uint8             instance_id,
                                       sx_uint8             port_num);

This function flips horizontally video images related to the specified instance of the given channel handle while the SMO grid is enabled.

Parameters:

  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle to flip its corresponding video image.
  • instance_id - You can display the same encoder or decoder handle in upto 4 grids within a SMO display. This field is used to identify which one of such grids. Valid range is 0 - 3.
  • port_num - The SMO port number where the first SMO display is one (1).

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • The function does not affect encoded or raw video frames associated with this channel handle. Additionally, since this is a very expensive operation, it may affect video encoding frame rate if too many SMO grids are mirrored.
  • This API requires firmware version 7.7.0.27 or higher. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_start_video_overlay (sx_uint32             board_index,
                                     sx_uint8              port_num,
                                     sdvr_rawv_formats_e   video_format,
                                     sdvr_chan_handle_t  * handle);

This function initializes the video output port on the specified board to display raw video frames sent by the DVR Application to be displayed on any SMO monitor that is capable of video output.

After the video output port is initialized, call sdvr_smo_add_overlay() to add video overlay objects. To display raw video frames in a video overlay object, you must call sdvr_get_video_overlay_buffer() and fill the buffer with one frame of raw video. Call sdvr_send_video_overlay() to send video overlay buffer the video overlay object.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to send the video.
  • port_num - The video out port number starting from port number 1.
  • video_format - The largest size raw video format that is going to be sent to the firmware. (e,g, Use SDVR_RAWV_FORMAT_RGB_655 if you are planning to send both YUV 4-2-0 and RGB-565 video frames overlay. Use SDVR_RAWV_FORMAT_YUV_4_2_0 if you are only sending YUV-4-2-0 video frame overlays.) Call sdvr_get_smo_attributes() to get a list of supported video format on this SMO port.
  • handle - Pointer to storage for the output channel handle, filled in on return. This handle should be used for all the subsequent call related to sending video to this SMO port.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • You need to call this function for each SMO port to which that you want to send raw video frames. Calling this function multiple times with identical parameters results in getting the previously created channel handle.

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_add_overlay(), sdvr_smo_add_direct_mem_overlay(), sdvr_stop_video_overlay(), sdvr_get_smo_attributes() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_stop_video_overlay (sdvr_chan_handle_t handle);

This function clears the video content of all the overlays, deletes all the overlay objects, and shuts down the video output port on the specified board.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel to close. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay() and should not be used after this call.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

See Also:

  • sdvr_start_video_overlay() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_add_overlay (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                 sx_uint16            width,
                                 sx_uint16            height,
                                 sx_uint8             layer_order,
                                 sx_uint8           * overlay_id);

This function creates a new blank video overlay object of the specified size on a particular SMO display. These overlay objects can be used to display menus, icons, the cursor, and so on per SMO display.

The DVR system does not limit the number of overlay objects that can be created per system as this number varies depending on the current memory usage. It is recommended for the DVR Application to limit the number of overlay objects to 64 per system.

After an overlay object is defined, you can use its overlay ID to populate the overlay object with raw YUV 4-2-0 video frames, hide/show, or move it around the SMO display.

For performance reason, it is recommended that you keep the video overlay objects for the entire session of your application.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel that is associated with an SMO display. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • width - The width of the overlay. This field is ignored if layer_order is set to zero. The width is assumed to be the full width of the SMO display.
  • height - The height of the overlay. This field is ignored if layer_order is set to zero. The height is assumed to be the full height of the SMO display.
  • layer_order - The relative ordering layer (Z-order) in comparison to other overlays. An overlay with the lower order number is placed beneath the one with a higher layer order number. The layer order of zero is a special layer. It is placed below all the video frames on the specified SMO display and then can only be one such layer defined. This layer can be used to specify a wall paper for the SMO display.
  • overlay_id - This parameter holds the overlay identifier if the overlay can be added successfully. This identifier must be passed to all the subsequent overlay function calls.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Overlay objects are always placed over the live or decoded SMO grid with the exception of overlay object of layer_order of zero.
  • There can only be one layer with layer_order of zero. The width and height of this overlay must be equal to the entire size of SMO display.

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_update_overlay(), sdvr_smo_add_overlay(), sdvr_start_video_overlay() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_add_overlay_ex (sdvr_chan_handle_t    handle,
                                    sx_uint16             width,
                                    sx_uint16             height,
                                    sx_uint8              layer_order,
                                    sx_uint8           *  overlay_id,
                                    void               ** vmem);

NOTE: This is a deprecated function and replaced with sdvr_smo_add_direct_mem_overlay().

In non-PowerPc or non-ARM environment this function acts exactly as sdvr_smo_add_overlay() and the vmem parameter is ignored. In PowerPc/ARM, the vmem parameter returns a pointer to a buffer where you can copy the Y-U-V 4-2-0 data associated to the overlay frame. Once this buffer is filled, you must call sdvr_smo_update_overlay() in order to send the frame to the SMO manager as oppose to calling the sdvr_send_video_overlay().

See sdvr_smo_add_overlay() for more description.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel that is associated with an SMO display. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • width - The width of the overlay. This field is ignored if layer_order is set to zero. The width is assumed to be the full width of the SMO display.
  • height - The height of the overlay. This field is ignored if layer_order is set to zero. The height is assumed to be the full height of the SMO display.
  • layer_order - The relative ordering layer (Z-order) in comparison to other overlays. An overlay with the lower order number is placed beneath the one with a higher layer order number. The layer order of zero is a special layer. It is placed below all the video frames on the specified SMO display and then can only be one such layer defined. This layer can be used to specify a wall paper for the SMO display.
  • overlay_id - This parameter holds the overlay identifier if the overlay can be added successfully. This identifier must be passed to all the subsequent overlay function calls.
  • vmem - Output - A pointer to a buffer to copy the Y-U-V 4-2-0 overlay video frame. This field is only available in PowerPc and ARM environment.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only available in PowerPc and ARM Linux. Otherwise, it is identical to sdvr_smo_add_overlay() where vmem parameter is ignored.
  • This function is marked deprecated as of SDK version 7.5. It is replaced by sdvr_smo_add_direct_mem_overlay().

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_update_overlay(), sdvr_smo_add_direct_mem_overlay(), sdvr_start_video_overlay() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_add_direct_mem_overlay (sdvr_chan_handle_t    handle,
                                            sdvr_overlay_t     *  overlay_info,
                                            void               ** vmem);

In non-PowerPc or ARM environment this function acts exactly as sdvr_smo_add_overlay() and the vmem parameter is ignored. In PowerPc/ARM, the vmem parameter returns a pointer to a buffer where you can copy the Y-U-V 4-2-0 or RGB data associated to the overlay frame. Once this buffer is filled, you must call sdvr_smo_update_overlay() in order to send the frame to the SMO manager as oppose to calling the sdvr_send_video_overlay().

See sdvr_smo_add_overlay() for more description.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel that is associated with an SMO display. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • overlay_info - Specify the video format, layer ordering, and the width and height of the overlay. Up on successful return, the overlay_id field is set that you need to use for any subsequent overlay calls.
  • vmem - Output - A pointer to a buffer to copy the Y-U-V 4-2-0 or RGB overlay video frame. This field is only available in PowerPc and ARM environment and will be ignored in other environments.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only available in PowerPc and ARM Linux. Otherwise, it is identical to sdvr_smo_add_overlay() where vmem parameter is ignored.

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_update_overlay(), sdvr_smo_add_overlay(), sdvr_start_video_overlay()
