sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_update_overlay (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                    sx_uint8             overlay_id);

This function calls the DMA engine to update the SMO overlay. After filling the buffer returned by sdvr_smo_add_direct_mem_overlay(), you must call this function in order to send the video frame overlay to the SMO manager.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel that is associated with an SMO display. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • overlay_id - The ID of the overlay to update its video frame.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only available in PowerPc or ARM environment.

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_add_direct_mem_overlay() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_duplicate_overlay (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                       sx_uint8             layer_order,
                                       sx_uint8             dup_overlay_id,
                                       sx_uint8           * overlay_id);

This function duplicates an existing video overlay object on the specified SMO display. The duplicated overlay objects have all the properties of a new overlay objects except that they share the same video frame. The duplicated overlay objects can be positioned or shown independently of each other within the specified SMO display.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel that is associated with an SMO display. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • layer_order - The relative ordering layer (Z-order) in comparison to other overlays. An overlay with the lower order number is placed beneath the one with a higher layer order number. There can only be one overlay with layer order of zero. The width and height overlay with layer order zero must be equal to the entire size of SMO display. This layer is placed below all other video frames on the specified SMO display. A possible usage of this layer is to define a wallpaper on a SMO display.
  • dup_overlay_id - The overlay ID to be duplicated.
  • overlay_id - On a successful return, it holds the overlay identifier. This must be used in all subsequent overlay calls to manipulate the overlay for a given SMO display.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Overlay objects are always placed over the live or decoded SMO grid with the exception of an overlay object of layer_order 0. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_delete_overlay (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                    sx_uint8             overlay_id);

This function deletes a previously defined overlay region on the specified SMO port.

This function allows you to add a new SMO overlay object when you reach the 255 maximum number of overlays allowed on an SMO port by deleting an existing overlay and adding a new one.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel that is associated with an SMO display. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • overlay_id - The overlay identifier to be removed from the SMO port.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • It is recommended that you avoid continuous deletion and addition of overlay objects if the total number of overlay objects on the SMO port is less than 64.
  • All the overlay objects are automatically deleted when sdvr_stop_video_overlay() is called. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_show_overlay (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                  sx_uint8             overlay_id,
                                  sx_uint8             alpha_value);

This function allows you to specify the visible intensity of a previously defined overlay region on the specified SMO port. You can make the overlay region to be completely transparent, completely visible, or any intensity in between.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel that is associated with an SMO display. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • overlay_id - The overlay identifier to be shown/hidden from the SMO display.
  • alpha_value - The alpha value used for blending of overlay image to the SMO display. The value range is from 1 (transparent ) to 128 (completely visible). Setting this parameter to zero stops the alpha blending of the overlay image to the screen leaving current image on the screen. Call sdvr_smo_clear_overlay() to remove or hide the overlay image from the screen.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • All the new overlays are created as hidden.
  • For the overlay with layer_order zero, any non-zero alpha value means completely show the overlay.

See Also:

  • sdvr_smo_clear_overlay() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_set_overlay_pos (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sx_uint8             overlay_id,
                                     sx_int16             top_left_x,
                                     sx_int16             top_left_y);

This function moves a previously defined overlay region within the specified SMO port.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel that is associated with an SMO display. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • overlay_id - The overlay identifier to be moved.
  • top_left_x and top_left_y - The top left coordinate of the overlay relative to the SMO display where (0,0) is the origin. If this coordinate includes any negative value, the overlay will be moved either to the left or above the SMO monitor, causing it to crop.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Depending on where the overlay is positioned, the video overlay maybe cropped within the SMO display.
  • Make sure the overlay_id is a valid ID. There is no error checking on this field for performance reasons. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_clear_overlay (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                   sx_uint8             overlay_id);

This function removes the last video frame associated with the given video layer number from the SMO display.

You need to call this function if you want to remove the last video layer from the SMO display but still send video frames to other layers.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of the output channel. This is the handle that was created and returned by the call to sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • overlay_id - The video out layer to clear from the SMO display.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Calling sdvr_stop_video_overlay() removes all the video frames from all the overlays from the specified SMO. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_set_overlay_from_file (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                           sx_uint8             overlay_id,
                                           sx_uint8             file_type,
                                           char               * file_name,
                                           sx_int16             top_left_x,
                                           sx_int16             top_left_y,
                                           sx_uint16            width,
                                           sx_uint16            height);

This function reads the first video frame from the specified raw video file and sends it to the given video overlay of the given SMO port handle.

In case of BMP file format, the entire BMP file is read and converted to YUV 4-2-0 before the frame is sent to the video overlay.

Parameters:

  • handle - The handle of the output channel that is associated with an SMO display. This handle was returned by sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • overlay_id - The overlay identifier.
  • file_type - The type of video frame. The valid types are: SDVR_RAWV_FORMAT_BMP for .bmp file format or SDVR_RAWV_FORMAT_YUV_4_2_0 for 4:2:0 YUV format.
  • file_name - The full path of the file from which to get one full video frame and send it to the SMO port.
  • top_left_x and top_left_y - The top left coordinate of the video frame relative to the overlay region where (0,0) is the origin. If this coordinate include any negative value, the overlay will be moved either to the left or above the SMO monitor, causing it to crop.
  • width - The width of the raw video frame. This field is ignored if the file_type is SDVR_RAWV_FORMAT_BMP.
  • height - The height of the raw video frame. This field is ignored if the file_type is SDVR_RAWV_FORMAT_BMP.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_video_overlay_buffer (sdvr_chan_handle_t             handle,
                                          sdvr_overlay_frame_attrib_t *  frame_attrib,
                                          sdvr_av_buffer_t            ** frame_buffer,
                                          sx_uint32                      wait_time);

This function returns an empty buffer large enough to hold the raw video frame to send to the SMO port. After an empty buffer is acquired, you must set its payload field with the raw video frame in the compact form. If your raw video frame is YUV format, then the Y plane must be followed by U and V planes without any gaps in between them. For RGB format make sure the size is less than 1.5 times of the maximum video frame size supported by the video standard of the board. (e,g, If a D1 NTSC video standard is specified when calling sdvr_board_connect(), this would be mean that the largest video frame size would be 720x480. In this case, the size of each RGB655 frame should not exceed 720x480x1.5. This is a board specific limitation that maybe removed at a future time.)

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of the output channel. This is the handle that was created and returned by the call to sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • frame_attrib - The overlay attributes such as its display order number, width, height, and so on. (See sdvr_overlay_frame_attrib_t for details of video overlay attributes.)
  • frame_buffer - Pointer to storage that will hold a pointer to the allocated buffer on successful return.
  • wait_time - Number of seconds to wait for a buffer to become available. Set this field to zero to return immediately if no buffer is available.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success.
  • SDVR_ERR_OUT_OF_MEMORY - Error code if the frame size is larger than the driver supports for this board.
  • SDVR_ERR_INVALID_FRAME_SIZE - Error code if the frame size is larger than the SMO display.
  • SDVR_ERR_BUF_NOT_AVAIL - Error code if the no buffer is available. You may want to call this function again after some wait.
  • SDVR_ERR_SEND_BUF_TOO_SMALL - Error code if the pre-allocated buffers are too small for the specified overlay video format. Make sure the video format specified at sdvr_start_video_overlay() is larger or equal to the specified overlay video format.
  • Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • The size of this buffer varies depending on the video format and the video width and height that are specified in the frame_attrib parameter. It is possible that very large buffer size cannot be obtained for RGB video format for most boards since this format requires twice as much memory as the specified frame size. Currently, most boards only allow upto 1.5 times of the largest possible video frame as is supported by the current board's video standard.
  • After this buffer's payload field is filled with the raw video buffer, you can send it to the DVR board using sdvr_send_video_overlay(). The function sdvr_send_video_overlay() releases the buffer after it is sent. In the event that you decide not to send this buffer to the DVR board, you must release it by calling sdvr_release_av_buffer(). 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_send_video_overlay (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                    sdvr_av_buffer_t   * frame_buffer);

This function sends one raw compact video frame to the video output and frees the buffer.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of the output channel. This is the handle that was created and returned by the call to sdvr_start_video_overlay().
  • frame_buffer - Pointer to a sdvr_av_buffer_t object that has been filled with a raw video frame.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This buffer must have been allocated by a call to sdvr_get_video_overlay_buffer(). Its payload should have been set by calling sdvr_get_buffer_payload_ptr() to get a pointer to the payload buffer and copying the raw video frame data. The raw video data must compacted. (e,g, If your raw video frame is YUV format, the Y plane must be followed by the U plane followed by the V plane without any gaps.) 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_freeze_smo_output (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                   sx_uint8    port_num,
                                   sx_bool     freeze);

This function freezes or unfreezes the display on the video output port on the specified board.

As you make calls to sdvr_smo_set_grid() to change SMO grids, you may notice the grids are being closed one by one before new ones are displayed. To prevent this display effect, you can call sdvr_freeze_smo_output() to freeze the frames displayed on the SMO monitor, call sdvr_smo_set_grid() to change the SMO grids, and then re-enable the SMO updating by sdvr_freeze_smo_output().

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board on which to freeze the video.
  • port_num - The video out port number starting from port number 1.
  • freeze - If true the video will be frozen, otherwise it will be unfrozen.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_osd_text_config (sx_uint32              board_index,
                                     sx_uint8               smo_port,
                                     sx_uint8               osd_id,
                                     sdvr_osd_config_ex_t * osd_text_config);

This function is used to configure the OSD text for an OSD item on a specific SMO port. The given OSD text applies to the entire SMO monitor and not to any particular video channel. The text associated with each OSD item can be up to 100 characters long but the actual display is limited to the size of the video and the starting location of the text. Additionally, you can specify whether to append a timestamp to the displayed text. Appending a time stamp reduces the number of characters that can be displayed for your OSD item.

After you configure an OSD item, you can show or hide its display state by calling sdvr_smo_osd_text_show(). The original state of the OSD item is hidden.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to set its SMO OSD.
  • smo_port - Enter the SMO port number for which to configure its OSD text where SMO port numbers start from one (1).
  • osd_id - The OSD item to be configured; where, osd_id zero corresponds to the first OSD, 1 to the second, and so on. The valid range is 0 to 4 in version 5.1 or later and 0 to 1 prior to version 5.1.
  • osd_text_config - This data structure defines the text and its position for display over the given SMO video as well as whether a timestamp should be appended to the text.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • The OSD text is not associated with displaying any SMO streaming. As a result, you may show or hide OSD text while no other video is being displayed on the SMO monitor.
  • This function is not supported by firmware version 7. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_osd_text_show (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                   sx_uint8    smo_port,
                                   sx_uint8    osd_id,
                                   sx_bool     show);

This function is used to control the display state of an OSD item for a given SMO display on a given DVR board. The OSD text is displayed as soon as SMO streaming is enabled for any channel handle on this SMO monitor.

This function must be called only after an OSD item is configured by calling sdvr_smo_osd_text_config() for the given SMO port.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to change the show state of its SMO OSD for a given SMO port.
  • smo_port - The SMO port number for which to change its OSD text display state where SMO port numbers start from one (1).
  • osd_id - The OSD item to show or hide; where, osd_id zero corresponds to the first OSD, 1 to the second, and so on. The valid range is 0 to 4 in version 5.1 or later and 0 to 1 prior to version 5.1.
  • show - If true, the OSD item is displayed; otherwise, it is not displayed.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • Call sdvr_smo_osd_text_show_all() to show or hide all the OSD texts on a specific SMO port as the same time. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_smo_osd_text_show_all (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                       sx_uint8    smo_port,
                                       sx_bool     show);

This function is used to control the display state of all OSD text items that have been configured for any given SMO display on a given DVR board. The OSD text is displayed as soon as SMO streaming is enabled for any channel handle on this SMO monitor.

This function must be called only after all the OSD items are configured by calling sdvr_smo_osd_text_config() for the given smo port.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to change the show state of its SMO OSD for a given SMO port.
  • smo_port - The SMO port number for which to change its OSD text display state where SMO port numbers start from one (1).
  • show - If true, all the OSD items are displayed at the same time; otherwise, they all get turned off.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • Call sdvr_smo_osd_text_show() to show or hide a specific OSD text on a specific SMO port. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_open_hmo_mirror (sx_uint32 board_index, sx_uint32 smo_port);

This function opens an HMO mirror output on one of the SMO ports in order to display the formated HMO grids output on the SMO port after the HMO UI preview is started. Note that at any one time, there can only be one HMO mirroring to any one of the SMO ports.

The actual HMO mirroring gets started after raw video streaming is enabled by calling sdvr_stream_raw_video() and the HMO preview is started using sdvr_ui_start_video_preview().

To redirect the mirroring of HMO output to any SMO ports, it is only needed to close the current HMO mirror output by calling sdvr_close_hmo_mirror() and re-open the new SMO port output by calling sdvr_open_hmo_mirror(). There is no need to start and stop the preview in between.

Refer to section Spot Monitor Output (SMO) for more information as how to use HMO mirror feature.

Parameters:

  • board_index - The board index of smo output.
  • smo_port - The smo port number starting from port number 1.

Returns:

  • This function returns SDVR_ERR_NONE on success.

Remarks:

  • This feature requires the usage of UI-SDK display mode 2. If you do not use, UI-SDK or UI-SDK mode 2 to display the HMO, no mirroring into the SMO port will take affect.
  • The application should not create an overlay with the z-order of zero or video format that is different than SDVR_RAWV_FORMAT_YUV_4_2_0 on the same smo_port where it is going to start HMO mirroring. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_close_hmo_mirror ();

This function stops mirroring of the HMO output to the opened SMO port.

Parameters:

  • None.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • The call to this function is ignored if sdvr_open_hmo_mirror() was not called prior calling this function..

10.14   Encode Monitor Output API

sdvr_err_e sdvr_create_emo (sx_uint32            board_index,
                            sdvr_chan_handle_t * emo_handle);

This function creates an Encoded Monitor Out (EMO) channel on a specific DVR board. EMO channels provide functionality similarly to SMO except that the constructed video frame is encoded as a D1 resolution video frame for SD SMO display and HD for HD SMO display before it is sent to the DVR Application.

After you create an EMO channel, you can add encoded or decoded channels to it by calling sdvr_set_emo_grid() and set its enable flag to true. Call sdvr_enable_encoder() using the EMO handle that is returned from this function to start receiving the formated encoded frame in your DVR Application's A/V frame callback function. When you are done, disable the grids by calling sdvr_set_emo_grid(), disable the encoder by calling sdvr_enable_encoder() and passing false as its enable flag. You can destroy the EMO channel and free all of its memory by calling sdvr_destroy_emo().

Parameters:

  • board_index - The number of the board in which to create the EMO channel. This is a zero-based number. It means the first board number is index zero, the second board number is index one, and so on.
  • emo_handle - Upon return, if there is no error, this field holds the channel handle.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • This function is only available on firmware version 6.x.
  • The encoder type of EMO is set to H.264-AVC and can not be changed. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_create_emo_port (sx_uint32            board_index,
                                 sx_uint32            smo_port,
                                 sdvr_chan_handle_t * emo_handle);

This function creates an Encoded Monitor Out (EMO) channel on a specific DVR board. EMO channels provide functionality similarly to SMO except that the constructed video frame is encoded as a D1 resolution video frame for SD SMO display and HD for HD SMO display before it is sent to the DVR Application.

Call sdvr_enable_encoder() using the EMO handle that is returned from this function to start receiving the formated encoded frame in your DVR Application's A/V frame callback function. To disable the EMO encoder channel, call sdvr_enable_encoder() and passing false as its enable flag. You can destroy the EMO channel and free all of its memory by calling sdvr_destroy_emo().

Parameters:

  • board_index - The number of the board in which to create the EMO channel. This is a zero-based number. It means the first board number is index zero, the second board number is index one, and so on.
  • smo_port - The smo port number starting from port number 1.
  • emo_handle - Upon return, if there is no error, this field holds the channel handle.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • This function requires firmware version 7.5 or higher on boards equipped with SMO.
  • The encoder type of EMO is set to H.264-AVC and can not be changed.

See also:

  • sdvr_destroy_emo(), sdvr_get_emo_attributes(), sdvr_enable_encoder() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_emo_attributes (sdvr_chan_handle_t     emo_handle,
                                    sdvr_emo_attribute_t * emo_attrib);

This function returns various attributes associated with the requested Encoded Monitor Out (EMO) channel. Call this function to find out the EMO's capabilities and video frame size.

Parameters:

  • emo_handle - The EMO channel to get its attributes. This handle was obtained from the call to sdvr_create_emo().
  • emo_attrib - A structure to hold the attributes of the requested EMO.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_emo_video_enc_params (sdvr_chan_handle_t            emo_handle,
                                          sdvr_emo_video_enc_params_t * enc_params);

This function is used to set the video parameters for an EMO channel. The encoder channel parameters are determined by the type of connected camera, the frame rate, and so on. All of these parameters are defined in sdvr_emo_video_enc_params_t, and are set using this function. Any video encoder parameter can be changed regardless of the encoder enable status. If the encoder is enabled, all the encoder parameter changes take place at the beginning of the next GOP, with the exception of frame rate and GOP size which take place immediately.

Parameters:

  • emo_handle - The EMO channel handle for which to set video encoder parameters.
  • enc_params - The parameters for the EMO channel. See sdvr_emo_video_enc_params_t for detailed information of each parameter.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_emo_grid (sdvr_chan_handle_t   emo_handle,
                              sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                              sdvr_emo_grid_t    * emo_grid);

This function is used to set the Encoded Monitor Output (EMO) grid pattern for a specific EMO channel.

You can divide the EMO into different grid patterns. Each tile of the EMO grid is defined by its left top most coordinate in pixels, and by the decimation of its original video resolution. Additionally, you can resize the grid either larger or smaller than the specified decimated video size.

The grid pattern on the constructed encoded frame is flexible and can be defined in various patterns (such as 4x4, 3x3, or 8x8 grids) as it applies to the resolution of the connected monitor. In addition to these fixed grid patterns, you can specify any irregular pattern as long it fits within the EMO video frame size.

Each tile of the grid is described by an sdvr_emo_grid_t data structure.

Each tile can either be enabled or disabled.

NOTE: You can include encoder and decoder channels in the EMO tile. For encoder channels, the live video is displayed. For decoder channels, the decoded (playback) video is displayed.

You can not assign the same channel to different tiles.

NOTE: The top left coordinates of each tile must be an even number (i.e., coordinates (0,5) or (1,2) are invalid).

Parameters:

  • emo_handle - The EMO channel handle for which to assign the specified encode or decode video channel.
  • handle - An encode or decode video channel handle whose output is displayed on this grid. See section Spot Monitor Output (SMO) for restriction in using decode video channel handle.
  • emo_grid - A pointer structure defining one grid on an EMO channel. Supported EMO resolution decimation are SDVR_VIDEO_RES_DECIMATION_EQUAL, SDVR_VIDEO_RES_CIF, and SDVR_VIDEO_RES_QCIF.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • The EMO grid is not displayed if it does not fit completely on one video frame size. You can get the size of EMO channel by calling sdvr_get_emo_attributes().
  • You must call this function with the grid's enable flag set to false prior to destroying the EMO channel.
  • This function is not supported by firmware version 7.0 or higher. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_destroy_emo (sdvr_chan_handle_t emo_handle);

This function destroys the given Encoded Monitor Out (EMO) channel handle.

Parameters:

  • emo_handle - The EMO channel to destroy. This handle was obtained from the call to sdvr_create_emo().

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • Before you can destroy the EMO channel, all the grids and the EMO channel video encoder must have been disabled.

10.15   Image Sensor Pipeline API for IP Camera

sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_gamma_value (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                 float                gamma_value);

This function sets the gamma value to be used by the gamma table.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to an IP Camera.
  • gamma_value - floating point number for gamma value range from 0.1 to 10.0

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_gamma_value() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_gamma_value (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                 float              * gamma_value);

This function returns the currently set gamma value.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to an IP Camera.
  • gamma_value - A pointer to a hold the current gamma value.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_gamma_value() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_ircut_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                      sdvr_ircut_t       * ircut);

This function returns the current ircut properties used by the camera's isp.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • ircut - A pointer to the returned ircut properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_ircut_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_ircut_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                      sdvr_ircut_t       * ircut);

This function sets ircut properties to control ircut of the IP camera.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • ircut - A pointer to the given ircut properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_ircut_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_shutter_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                        sdvr_shutter_t     * shutter);

This function returns the current shutter properties used by the camera's isp.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
    • shutter - A pointer to the returned shutter properties struct.
  • Returns:
    • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.
  • Remarks:
    • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.
  • See Also:
    • sdvr_set_shutter_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_shutter_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                        sdvr_shutter_t     * shutter);

This function sets shutter properties to control shutter of the IP camera.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • shutter - A pointer to the given shutter properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_shutter_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_iris_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sdvr_iris_t        * iris);

This function returns the current iris properties used by the camera's isp.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • iris - A pointer to the returned iris properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_iris_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_iris_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sdvr_iris_t        * iris);

This function sets iris properties to control iris of the IP camera.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • iris - A pointer to the given iris properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_iris_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_gain_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sdvr_gain_t        * gain);

This function returns the current gain properties used by the camera's isp.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • gain - A pointer to the returned gain properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_gain_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_gain_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sdvr_gain_t        * gain);

This function sets gain properties to control gain of the IP camera.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • gain - A pointer to the given gain properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_gain_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_exposure_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                         sdvr_exposure_t    * exposure);

This function returns the current exposure properties used by the camera's isp.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • exposure - A pointer to the returned exposure properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_exposure_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_exposure_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                         sdvr_exposure_t    * exposure);

This function sets exposure properties to control exposure of the IP camera.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • exposure - A pointer to the given exposure properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_exposure_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_focus_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                      sdvr_focus_t       * focus);

This function returns the current focus properties used by the camera's isp.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • focus - A pointer to the returned focus properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_focus_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_focus_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                      sdvr_focus_t       * focus);

This function sets focus properties to control focus of the IP camera.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • focus - A pointer to the given focus properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_focus_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_wdr_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                    sdvr_wdr_t         * wdr);

This function returns the current wdr properties used by the camera's isp.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • wdr - A pointer to the returned wdr properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_wdr_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_wdr_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                    sdvr_wdr_t         * wdr);

This function sets wdr properties to control wdr of the IP camera.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • wdr - A pointer to the given wdr properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_wdr_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_wb_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                   sdvr_wb_t          * wb);

This function returns the current white balance properties used by the camera's isp.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • wb - A pointer to the returned wb properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_wb_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_wb_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                   sdvr_wb_t          * wb);

This function sets wb properties to control white balance of the IP camera.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • wb - A pointer to the given wb properties struct.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_wb_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_img_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                    sdvr_img_t         * img);

This function returns the current image properties value associated with an IP camera's ISP.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • img - A pointer to the returned image properties structure.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board. When connecting to a DVR/VRM board, use sdvr_get_video_in_params() that goes into Alvin to get on-board video decoder's parameters.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_img_properties(), sdvr_get_video_in_params() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_img_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                    sdvr_img_t         * img);

This function sets image properties to control IP camera's ISP.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • img - A pointer to the given image properties structure.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only available when connecting to an IP Camera board. When connecting to a DVR/VRM board, use sdvr_set_video_in_params() that goes into Alvin to set on-board video decoder's parameters.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_img_properties(), sdvr_set_video_in_params() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_enable_motion_map (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                   sx_bool              enable);

This function enables/disables ISP motion map generation. Once motion map is enabled, for every video frame a motion map buffer will be sent. This buffer can be retrieved like any other frame buffer by calling sdvr_get_stream_buffer(). The payload associated with SDVR_FRAME_MOTION_MAP buffer type includes motion values. The motion values are represented as 8 bits per one 128x128 block in network byte order, scanning the image from left to right and from top to bottom. The width represents number of 128x128 blocks in horizontal direction (and therefore number of motion values per image line) and height represents number of blocks in the vertical direction. The aggregate motion is the maximum of all motion values for the whole image and is followed by individual motion values, starting from top left corner. Aggregate motion and motion values are each 8 bit unsigned integers.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • enable - 1 enable, 0 disable.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only available when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_stream_buffer() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_flip_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sdvr_flip_t        * flip);

This function returns the current image flipping properties value associated with an IP camera's ISP.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • flip - A pointer to the returned image properties structure.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only applicable when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_set_flip_properties() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_flip_properties (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sdvr_flip_t        * flip);

This function sets image flipping properties to control IP camera's ISP.

Parameters:

  • handle - Handle of an encoder channel connected to a IP Camera.
  • flip - A pointer to the given image properties structure.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • This function is only available when connecting to an IP Camera board.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_flip_properties()

10.16   Audio/Video File Container API

sdvr_err_e sdvr_file_start_recording (sdvr_chan_handle_t         handle,
                                      sx_uint8                   sub_enc,
                                      sdvr_rec_specification_t * rec_spec,
                                      sx_bool                    enable_encoder);

This function saves the encoded audio and video frames for the given sub-encoder of the specified encoder channel into the given file name. The generated a/v file container type depends on the requested file type and the CODEC type associated to the sub-encoder.

You may optionally enable the interested video sub-encoder associated to this camera as part of this call or separately by calling sdvr_enable_encoder() before or after this call. It is recommended not to enable the video encoder prior to this call since potentially some video frames can be lost.

As part of this call, you can control whether to save all the A/V frames associated to a camera into one file or into multiple files according to a recording policy.

Call sdvr_file_stop_recording() to stop saving of encoded frames and optionally to disable the corresponding encoder.

NOTE: It is highly advised to keep recording time of SDVR_FILE_TYPE_MOV file to no more than half an hour of video. Closing long duration of recording in such file format may result in system instability or video frame drop due to the time that is required to format the video index table and write to the end of file file.

Parameters:

  • handle - The channel handle for which to record audio and video frames.
  • sub_enc - The encoder sub_channel for which to save its encoded audio and video frames.
  • rec_spec - The recording specification. See sdvr_rec_specification_t for details.
  • enable_encoder - If set to true, the corresponding video encoder to the requested sub_enc will be enabled after the file is created. If this field is set to false, you must call sdvr_enable_encoder() in order to start the encoder.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

Even though this function is called to save the encoded frames, the DVR Application is still notified by the callback function as the audio and video frames arrive. You can choose to ignore these frames or call sdvr_get_stream_buffer() to get the frames and perform additional processing.

This function should not be used if the encoder's resolution decimation is set to SDVR_VIDEO_RES_CUSTOM. 

sdvr_err_e sdvr_file_stop_recording (sdvr_chan_handle_t   handle,
                                     sx_uint8             sub_enc,
                                     sx_bool              disable_encoder);

Call this function to stop saving of encoded audio and video frames for the given sub-encoder of the specified encoder channel that is recording.

You may optionally disable the interested video sub-encoder associated to this camera as part of this call or separately by calling sdvr_enable_encoder() before or after this call. It is recommended not to disable the video encoder prior to this call since you could potentially loose some video frames.

Parameters:

  • handle - The channel handle for which to stop recording audio/video frames.
  • sub_chan_enc - The encoder sub-channel to stop recording.
  • disable_encoder - If set to true, the corresponding video encoder to the requested sub_enc will be disabled after the file is closed. If this field is set to false, you must call sdvr_enable_encoder() in order to disable the encoder.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_file_open_read (sdvr_file_read_desc_t * file_info,
                                sdvr_file_handle_t    * file_handle);

Call this function to open a A/V file container in order to extract the encoded A/V frames. Once the file is opened for reading, you can read one frame at a time by calling sdvr_file_read_frame(). Call sdvr_file_close() to close the file.

Parameters:

  • file_info - The structure describing the A/V container file to read and extract A/V frames according to the specified criteria.
  • file_handle - Up on successful return, it holds the file handle to be used in subsequent file read calls.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • After an A/V file container is opened for read, it should not be used for recording. In order to extract A/V frames from a file that is in use for recording (Tivo mode), recording must start prior to the call to this function. Tivo mode is not supported by elementary stream files. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_file_open_write (sdvr_rec_specification_t * rec_spec,
                                 sdvr_file_avtrack_info_t * avtrack_info,
                                 sdvr_file_handle_t       * file_handle);

Call this function to open a A/V file container in order to add encoded A/V frames. Once the file is opened for writing, you can add one audio or video frame at a time by calling sdvr_file_write_frame(). You can specify a number of recording specification when opening the file for writing. These are information such as the folder where the file should be created, a prefix for the file name, possibly append a timestamp to the file name prefix, limit the number of A/V frames that can be recorded in a file, and so on. Two different possible actions occur in the event the number of frames in a file is limited. These action are dependent on append timestamp field of rec_spec parameter.

a) The current recording file will be closed and a new one with the timestamp appended to the file prefix will be opened once the number of requested frames are added to the file and if the append timestamp is set to true.

b) The current recording file will be truncated once the number of requested frames are added to the file but the append timestamp is set to false before the new frames are added.

NOTE: All files will start with key video frames. This means the new file will not be created if the number of requested frames reaches in the middle of the GOP until the GOP finishes.

Call sdvr_file_close() to close the file.

Parameters:

  • rec_spec - The structure describing the name of the file to record, its folder, and how often. See sdvr_rec_specification_t for detailed information.
  • avtrack_info - The structure describing the audio and video codec. Set the audio codec to SDVR_AUDIO_ENC_NONE if you are not interested to record the audio frames.
  • file_handle - Up on successful return, it holds the file handle to be used in subsequent file read calls.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

Remarks:

  • Adding of audio frames is not supported by all the A/V file containers. (i,e, elementary stream files.)
  • This function fails if the full path to the request file does not exist.
  • It is the DVR Application responsibility to use mutex in order to serialize writing of video frames and closing of recorded file when is done in two different threads. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_file_close (sdvr_file_handle_t file_handle);

Call this function to close a A/V file container that was opened for reading.

Parameters:

  • file_handle - The file handle to close. This file handle was obtained from the call to sdvr_file_open_read() or sdvr_file_open_write().

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_file_read_frame (sdvr_file_handle_t   file_handle,
                                 sx_uint8           * av_frame_data,
                                 sx_uint32          * av_frame_data_size,
                                 sx_uint8           * av_frame_type,
                                 sx_uint64          * av_frame_timestamp);

Call this function to extract the next A/V frame from an A/V file container after it was opened by sdvr_file_open_read().

Parameters:

  • file_handle - The file handle to an A/V file container. This file handle was obtained from the call to sdvr_file_open_read().
  • av_frame_data - A pointer to a buffer holding the A/V frame data.
  • av_frame_data_size - As input, it should be set to the maximum size of av_frame_data buffer. Up on successful return, it gets set to the actual number of bytes in av_frame_data.
  • av_frame_type - Up on successful return, it holds the frame type of av_frame_data.
  • av_frame_timestamp - Up on successful return, it holds the timestamp associated with this frame. This field is ignored for SDVR_FILE_TYPE_ELEMENTARY file type. The time stamp for SDVR_FILE_TYPE_MOV and SDVR_FILE_TYPE_STRETCH is based on 90 KHz clock for all the video frames. It is adjusted according to the specified audio sampling rate for the audio frames.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.
  • SDVR_ERR_EOF - Error code when reached the end of file.
  • SDVR_ERR_NO_MORE_FRAMES - Error code when reached to the end of file but the file is also open for recording and more A/V frame maybe written.

Remarks:

  • If you are planning to send this frame to the DVR board for decoding, call sdvr_alloc_av_buffer_wait() to acquire an A/V buffer. Otherwise, call sdvr_file_alloc_av_buffer(). You can access the acquired payload and the allocated payload size associated with the A/V buffer by calling sdvr_av_buf_payload(). 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_file_write_frame (sdvr_file_handle_t   file_handle,
                                  sdvr_av_buffer_t   * av_buffer);

Call this function to add A/V frames to an A/V file container.

After you open an A/V file container by calling sdvr_file_open_write(), you can add the A/V frames that are sent from the DVR board to the file one at a time by calling this function.

Parameters:

  • file_handle - The file handle to an A/V file container. This file handle was obtained from the call to sdvr_file_open_write().
  • av_buffer - A pointer to an encoded A/V frame buffer that was possibly obtained from sdvr_get_stream_buffer(). NOTE: The timestamp set as part of this buffer assumes to be based on 100KHz which is the DVR Board's default.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_file_get_avtrack_from_file (char                     * file_path,
                                            sdvr_file_type_e           file_type,
                                            sdvr_file_avtrack_info_t * avtrack_info);

Call this function to get information regarding the audio/video track in the A/V file container that is not currently opened.

Parameters:

  • file_path - The pointer to the full file path of the A/V file container.
  • file_type - The type of A/V file container. See sdvr_file_type_e for more information. NOTE: It is assumed that the video codec inside the file type of SDVR_FILE_TYPE_ELEMENTARY is h.264-svc.
  • avtrack_info - Holds the audio/video track information. (i.e. the video frame size). See sdvr_file_avtrack_info_t for more information.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list. 
sdvr_av_buffer_t * sdvr_file_alloc_av_buffer (sx_uint32 payload_size);

A utility function to allocate an A/V buffer that holds the specified payload size for the purpose of file read/write operation. The buffer returned can not be used to send this frame to the board or any other operations other than file read/write.

You need to use this function in the event that you are converting one file format to another. In this case, you read the A/V frame data into the buffer returned from this function by calling sdvr_file_read_frame() and pass the result to sdvr_file_write_frame().

Call sdvr_file_free_av_buffer() to free the buffer.

Parameters:

  • payload_size - The maximum size of payload for this A/V buffer that can be set. NOTE: This size should be large enough to hold one full A/V frame buffer.

Returns:

  • NULL if failed to allocate the requested size of memory. Otherwise, a pointer to the allocated buffer.

Remark:

  • You need to use the various A/V buffer APIs to set the payload, payload size, frame type, and so one. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_file_free_av_buffer (sdvr_av_buffer_t *av_buffer);

A utility function to free the buffer that was allocated using sdvr_file_alloc_av_buffer().

Note: You should not pass A/V buffers obtained from any other calls than sdvr_file_alloc_av_buffer().

Parameters:

  • av_buffer - The A/V buffer that was obtained from sdvr_file_alloc_av_buffer() to be freed.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, SDVR_ERR_INVALID_ARG if the av_buffer is not invalid.

10.17   RS485, GPIO, and TWI Communication API

sdvr_err_e sdvr_init_uart (sx_uint32   board_index,
                           sx_uint32   baud_rate,
                           sx_uint8    data_bits,
                           sx_uint8    stop_bits,
                           sx_uint8    parity_enable,
                           sx_uint8    parity_even);

This function is used to initialize the UART port on the Stretch chip set to talk to the RS-485.

Parameters:

  • board_index - The board number. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • baud_rate - The output baud rate. Must be between 50 and 19200.
  • data_bits - Number of data bits. Valid values are 5-8.
  • stop_bits - Number of stop bits. Valid values are 1 and 2.
  • parity_enable - If this field is set to zero, parity is disabled. If set to a nonzero value, parity is enabled.
  • parity_even - If this field is set to zero, odd parity is used. If set to a nonzero value, even parity is used. This field is ignored if parity is disabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

See Also:

  • sdvr_read_uart(), sdvr_write_uart() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_read_uart (sx_uint32   board_index,
                           sx_uint8  * data_count_read,
                           sx_uint8    max_data_size,
                           sx_uint8  * data);

This function is used to read up to requested number of 8-bit characters from the RS485 port.

You must initialize the UART by calling sdvr_init_uart()and sent commands to receive data before calling this function.

It is possible for the data not to be ready on the port at the time of calling this function. In this case, you need to call this function multiple time while the actual number of bytes received is zero or is less than the expected amount.

Parameters:

  • board_index - The board number. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • data_count_read - A pointer to a variable that holds the actual number characters read upon successful return. This count is less than or equal to the max_data_size. A value of zero means, there is no data available at the port.
  • max_data_size - The maximum number of bytes request to read from the board. NOTE: The actual returned bytes maybe less than the requested ones.
  • data - A character pointer long enough to hold the maximum number of bytes request.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

See Also:

  • sdvr_init_uart(), sdvr_write_uart() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_write_uart (sx_uint32   board_index,
                            sx_uint8    count,
                            sx_uint8  * data);

This function is used to write a number of 8-bit characters to the RS485 port.

Before calling this function, the UART must be initialized by calling sdvr_init_uart().

Parameters:

  • board_index - The board number. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • count - Number of bytes to transmit.
  • data - The data bytes to transmit. The number of valid bytes in the array is determined by the count field.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise, see the error code list.

See Also:

  • sdvr_init_uart(), sdvr_read_uart() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_read_gpio (sx_uint32   board_index,
                           sx_uint8    pe_id,
                           sx_uint8    pin_num,
                           sx_uint8  * value,
                           sx_uint8  * direction);

This function reads the current value and direction of a given GPIO pin number on a given PE within the specified board.

Parameters:

  • board_index - The board number. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • pe_id - The ID of the PE to execute the operation. This is a zero based number.
  • pin_num - GPIO pin number.
  • value - A pointer to hold the current value of the pin. 0 or 1.
  • direction - A pointer to hold the direction of the pin, IN (0) or OUT (1).

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Not all products support GPIO control. In particular, this feature is not supported by S6 products.

See Also:

  • sdvr_write_gpio() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_write_gpio (sx_uint32   board_index,
                            sx_uint8    pe_id,
                            sx_uint8    pin_num,
                            sx_uint8    value,
                            sx_uint8    direction);

This function sets the value and direction of a given GPIO pin number on a given PE within the specified board.

WARNING: Incorrect use of the GPIO pins can cause the system to hang or malfunction in unpredictable ways. A close study of the schematics for the target board is advised.

Parameters:

  • board_index - The board number. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • pe_id - The ID of the PE to execute the operation. This is a zero based number.
  • pin_num - GPIO pin number.
  • value - The value of the pin to set, 0 or 1.
  • direction - The direction of the pin to set, IN (0) or OUT (1).

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Not all products support GPIO control. In particular, this feature is not supported by S6 products.

See Also:

  • sdvr_read_gpio() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_read_twi_regval (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                 sx_uint8    pe_id,
                                 sx_uint8    ra_16bit,
                                 sx_uint16   twi_addr,
                                 sx_uint16   reg_addr,
                                 sx_uint16 * reg_data);

This function read device registers on any device residing on the TWI bus.

WARNING: Incorrect programming of any TWI device can cause the system to hang or malfunction in unpredictable ways. Please study the manual for the device being controlled, and make sure that any changes made do not conflict with the firmware's use of the device.

Parameters:

  • board_index - The board number. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • pe_id - The ID of the PE to execute the operation. This is a zero based number.
  • ra_16bit - If non-zero, use 16-bit register address. If zero, use 8-bit register address.
  • twi_addr - TWI bus address of the target device.
  • reg_addr - Address of register to be read.
  • reg_data - A pointer to hold the current value of the register.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Not all products support TWI control. In particular, this feature is not supported by S6 products.
  • We only verify that the TWI device exists but will not validate any parameters.

See Also:

  • sdvr_write_twi_regval() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_write_twi_regval (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                  sx_uint8    pe_id,
                                  sx_uint8    ra_16bit,
                                  sx_uint16   twi_addr,
                                  sx_uint16   reg_addr,
                                  sx_uint16   reg_data);

This function writes device registers on any device residing on the TWI bus.

WARNING: Incorrect programming of any TWI device can cause the system to hang or malfunction in unpredictable ways. Please study the manual for the device being controlled, and make sure that any changes made do not conflict with the firmware's use of the device.

Parameters:

  • board_index - The board number. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • pe_id - The ID of the PE to execute the operation. This is a zero based number.
  • ra_16bit - If non-zero, use 16-bit register address. If zero, use 8-bit register address.
  • twi_addr - TWI bus address of the target device.
  • reg_addr - Address of register to be written.
  • reg_data - The value to be written to the device register.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • Not all products support TWI control. In particular, this feature is not supported by S6 products.
  • We only verify that the TWI device exists but will not validate any parameters.

See Also:

  • sdvr_read_twi_regval()

10.18   Sensors and Relays API

sdvr_err_e sdvr_config_sensors (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                sx_uint32   sensor_enable_map,
                                sx_uint32   edge_triggered_map);

NOTE: This is a depreciated function and should not be used. This function is replaced with sdvr_config_sensors_64().

This function is used to specify how each sensor should be triggered as well as how to enable or disable each of the sensors on each SDVR board.

Sensors can be either edge-triggered or level-sensitive. You can specify the method to use to determine whether a sensor is triggered.

A notification message will be sent to the DVR Application for every sensor that is enabled and is triggered. The sensors that are disabled receive no notification messages.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board whose sensors you want to set. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • sensor_enable_map - A bit map corresponding to each sensor to indicate whether it is enabled. The least most significant (LMS) bit of this map corresponds to the first sensor, the next LMS bit to the second sensor, and so on. You can determine the number of sensors from the board configuration data structure. The value of 1 for a bit means that the sensor is enabled for the corresponding sensor, and 0 means it is disabled. Default status of the sensors is disabled.
  • edge_triggered_map - A bit map corresponding to each sensor to indicate whether it is edge triggered. The least most significant (LMS) bit of this map corresponds to the first sensor, the next LMS bit to the second sensor, and so on. You can determine the number of sensors from the board configuration data structure. The value of 1 for a bit means that the sensor is edge triggered for the corresponding sensor, and 0 means it is level sensitive. This field is not used any more.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise see the error code list. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_config_sensors_64 (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                   sx_uint64   sensor_enable_map);

This function is used to specify which each sensor is allowed to be triggered.

A notification message will be sent to the DVR Application for every sensor that is enabled and is triggered. The sensors that are disabled receive no notification messages.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board whose sensors you want to set. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • sensor_enable_map - A bit map corresponding to each sensor to indicate whether it is enabled. The least most significant (LMS) bit of this map corresponds to the first sensor, the next LMS bit to the second sensor, and so on. You can determine the number of sensors from the board configuration data structure. The value of 1 for a bit means that the sensor is enabled for the corresponding sensor, and 0 means it is disabled. Default status of the sensors is disabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise see the error code list.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_sensors_state_64(), sdvr_get_sensors_64(), sdvr_enable_sensor() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_enable_sensor (sx_uint32   board_index,
                               sx_uint32   sensor_num,
                               sx_bool     enable);

This function is used to enable or disable a sensor on each SDVR board.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board whose sensor you want to set. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • sensor_num - The number of the sensor - a board with M sensors has the sensors numbered sequentially from 0 to M-1 (see schematics for position of sensors number 0, 1, etc.). You can determine the number of sensors from the board configuration data structure.
  • enable - If true, the sensor is enabled, and if triggered you are notified. If false, the sensor is disabled and no notification is sent to the DVR Application. Default status of the sensor is disabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise see the error code list.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_sensors_state_64(), sdvr_get_sensors_64(), sdvr_config_sensors_64() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_sensors (sx_uint32   board_index,
                             sx_uint32 * sensor_enable_map,
                             sx_uint32 * edge_triggered_map);

NOTE: This is a depreciated function and should not be used. This function is replaced with sdvr_get_sensors_64().

This function returns the enable status of the sensor inputs.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to be queried.
  • sensor_enable_map - A pointer to a bit a map corresponding to each sensor to indicate whether it is enabled. The least most significant (LMS) bit of this map corresponds to the first sensor, the next LMS bit to the second sensor, and so on. The value of 1 for a bit means that the sensor is enabled for the corresponding sensor, and 0 means it is disabled. Default status of the sensors is disabled.
  • edge_triggered_map - A pointer to a bit map corresponding to each sensor to indicate whether it is edge triggered. The least most significant (LMS) bit of this map corresponds to the first sensor, the next LMS bit to the second sensor, and so on. The value of 1 for a bit means that the sensor is edge triggered for the corresponding sensor, and 0 means it is level sensitive. This field is not currently used.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • You can determine the number of sensors from the board configuration data structure.
  • This function should not be used if number of sensor inputs exceed 32. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_sensors_64 (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                sx_uint64 * sensor_enable_map);

This function returns the enable status of the sensor inputs.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to be queried.
  • sensor_enable_map - A pointer to a bit a map corresponding to each sensor to indicate whether it is enabled. The least most significant (LMS) bit of this map corresponds to the first sensor, the next LMS bit to the second sensor, and so on. The value of 1 for a bit means that the sensor is enabled for the corresponding sensor, and 0 means it is disabled. Default status of the sensors is disabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • You can determine the number of sensors from the board configuration data structure.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_sensors_state_64(), sdvr_enable_sensor(), sdvr_config_sensors_64() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_sensors_state (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                   sx_uint32 * sensor_state_map);

NOTE: This is a depreciated function and should not be used. This function is replaced with sdvr_get_sensors_state_64().

This function returns the state of each sensor inputs.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to be queried.
  • sensor_state_map - A pointer to a bit map corresponding to each sensor input to indicate whether its input has been grounded. The least significant bit (LSB) of this map corresponds to the first sensor, the next bit to the second sensor, and so on. The value of 1 for a bit means that the corresponding input has been grounded, and 0 means it is at 5 Volts.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • You can determine the number of sensors from the board configuration data structure.
  • This function should not be used if number of sensor inputs exceed 32. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_sensors_state_64 (sx_uint32   board_index,
                                      sx_uint64 * sensor_state_map);

This function returns the state of each sensor inputs.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to be queried.
  • sensor_state_map - A pointer to a bit map corresponding to each sensor input to indicate whether its input has been grounded. The least significant bit (LSB) of this map corresponds to the first sensor, the next bit to the second sensor, and so on. The value of 1 for a bit means that the corresponding input has been grounded, and 0 means it is at 5 Volts.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • You can determine the number of sensors from the board configuration data structure.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_sensors_64(), sdvr_enable_sensor(), sdvr_config_sensors_64() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_relays (sx_uint32   board_index,
                            sx_uint32 * relays_status);

NOTE: This is a depreciated function and should not be used. This function is replaced with sdvr_get_relays_64().

This function returns the status of the relay outputs.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to be queried.
  • relay_status - Pointer to a bit map storage where the current relay status is returned. Each bit of the bit map identifies the enable state of each relay ordered from the least most significant (LMS) bit corresponding to the first relay. The value of 1 for a bit means that the relay is enabled for the corresponding relay, and 0 means it is disabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • You can determine the number of relays from the board configuration data structure.
  • This function should not be used if number of relays on board exceed 32. 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_get_relays_64 (sx_uint32   board_index,
                               sx_uint64 * relays_status);

This function returns the status of the relay outputs.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board to be queried.
  • relay_status - Pointer to a bit map storage where the current relay status is returned. Each bit of the bit map identifies the enable state of each relay ordered from the least most significant (LMS) bit corresponding to the first relay. The value of 1 for a bit means that the relay is enabled for the corresponding relay, and 0 means it is disabled.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

Remarks:

  • You can determine the number of relays from the board configuration data structure.

See Also:

  • sdvr_trigger_relay() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_trigger_relay (sx_uint32   board_index,
                               sx_uint32   relay_num,
                               sx_bool     is_triggered);

This function is used to trigger relays on each SDVR board.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board whose relay you want to set. This is a zero based number. It means the first board number is index zero, second board number is index one, and so on.
  • relay_num - The number of the relay - a board with M relays has the relays numbered sequentially from 0 to M-1 (see schematics for position of relay number 0, 1, and so on). You can determine the number of relays from the board configuration data structure.
  • is_triggered - If true, the relay is triggered. If false, the relay is reset.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE - On success. Otherwise see the error code list.

See Also:

  • sdvr_get_relays_64() 
sdvr_err_e sdvr_set_led (sx_uint32         board_index,
                         sdvr_led_type_e   led_type,
                         sx_uint8          led_num,
                         sx_bool           enable);

This function sets the state of an LED within a given LED type on the board.

Parameters:

  • board_index - Index of the board.
  • led_type - The type of LED to set its enable status.
  • led_num - A zero based LED number within the LED type group. The first LED number is specified by zero (0), second LED number is one (1), and so on.
  • enable - Set to true to turn the LED on, false to turn it off.

Returns:

  • SDVR_ERR_NONE on success. Otherwise, see the error list for possible error codes.

10.19   Miscellaneous

#define SDVR_FOSD_MODULE_ID (osd_id) { ... }

Get module id from an OSD id 

#define SDVR_FOSD_STREAM_ID (osd_id) { ... }

Get stream id from an OSD id 

#define SDVR_FOSD_TEXT_ID (osd_id) { ... }

Get OSD text id from an OSD id 

#define SDVR_FOSD_OSD_ID (mid, sid, tid) { ... }

Set an OSD id by module id, stream id, and osd text id

mid - module ID specifies the place to apply OSD. Its valid values are defined at sdvr_fosd_module_id_t.

sid - stream ID specifies the stream to apply OSD. Its valid values are specified by sdvr_fosd_spec. For example, a camera encoder job supports 2 stream encodings, 2 HMO outputs, and 2 SMO outputs (ports). The ranges of the stream IDs for encoder, HMO output, and SMO output are 0 to 1. For example, an IP camera job supports 4 stream encodings, 0 HMO output, and 1 SMO output (port). The range of the stream IDs for encoder is 0 to 3. The valid value of the stream IDs for SMO output is 0.

tid - text ID specifies the OSD line to apply OSD. Its valid values are specified by sdvr_fosd_spec. For example, the valid range is 0 to 4, if the number of OSDs is 5.
